message_1: Suppose we have the complex-valued function $f(z)=z^2$. Find a conformal mapping that maps the unit disk $|z|<1$ onto the right half-plane $\text{Re}(w)>0$, and maps the point $z=0$ to $w=1$.
message_2:
To find a conformal mapping that maps the unit disk $|z|<1$ onto the right half-plane $\text{Re}(w)>0$, and maps the point $z=0$ to $w=1$, we can use the following steps:

1. Map the unit disk $|z|<1$ to the upper half-plane $\text{Im}(z)>0$ using the MÃ¶bius transformation $g(z) = \frac{z - i}{z + i}$.

2. Map the upper half-plane $\text{Im}(z)>0$ to the right half-plane $\text{Re}(w)>0$ using the exponential function $h(z) = e^{i\pi z}$.

3. Translate the right half-plane so that the point $z=0$ is mapped to $w=1$. This can be done using the translation function $k(w) = w + 1$.

Now, we can combine these mappings to obtain the desired conformal mapping:

$$f(z) = k(h(g(z))) = k(e^{i\pi(\frac{z - i}{z + i})}) + 1$$

This conformal mapping maps the unit disk $|z|<1$ onto the right half-plane $\text{Re}(w)>0$, and maps the point $z=0$ to $w=1$.
